988 F.Supp. 296 (1997)
NYCAL CORPORATION, Plaintiff,
v.
INOCO PLC and Downshire N.V., Defendants.
No. 96 CIV. 7159 LAK.
United States District Court, S.D. New York.
December 12, 1997.
*297 Jeffrey E. Glen, DeForest & Duer, New York City, for Plaintiff.
Lawrence A. Blatte, Rosen & Reade, L.L.P., New York City, for Defendants.

MEMORANDUM OPINION
KAPLAN, District Judge.
This lawsuit involves a claim by Nycal Corporation ("Nycal") that it was defrauded by Inoco PLC and Downshire N.V. (collectively, "Inoco") in connection with Nycal's 1991 purchase of a majority interest in Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation ("Gulf") from Inoco. Inoco seeks summary judgment dismissing the complaint on the ground that it is barred by a release contained in a settlement agreement previously executed by Nycal. Nycal rejoins that the release does not cover its present claim and, in any case, itself was obtained by fraud.

Facts
The essential facts in this dispute are as follows.[1]
*298 In early 1991, negotiations began between Nycal's chairman, Graham Ferguson Lacey, and David Rowland, president of Gulf and vice chairman of Inoco, concerning the possibility of Nycal acquiring Inoco's controlling interest in Gulf. On May 24, 1991, Nycal entered into a Stock Purchase Agreement with Inoco (the "SPA") by which it agreed to purchase Inoco's interest in Gulf for approximately $34 million. The transaction closed on July 12, 1991.
